case_name: Chaurasia Limestone Company v. Rewa Coalfields Limited

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 276 of 1958 is before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 276 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal arises from judgment and decree dated August 6, 1955 of Judicial Commissioner Court at Rewa, V.P. in First Civil Appeal No. 16 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 6, 1955, of the, Judicial Commissioners companyrt, at Rewa, V. P. in First Civil Appeal No. 16 of 1955.

facts.text: Respondent Rewa Coalfields Limited has coal-mines at Burhar and Umaria with registered office at Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Rewa Coalfields Limited is a registered companypany whose companyl-mines are situated at Burhar and Umaria. Its registered office is at Calcutta.

facts.text: Appellant is Chaurasia Limestone Company, Satna, Vindhya Pradesh, partners Ramlal, Motilal and Chhotelal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a firm, Chaurasia Limestone Company, Satna, Vindhya Pradesh, by name and the three brothers Ramlal, Motilal and Chhotelal are its partners.

facts.text: Appellant purchased 3,307 tons of coal from respondent at Rs. 14-9-0 per ton between January 1952 and March 1953, total price Rs. 48,158-4-0.

anchor.surface_text: According to respondents case the appellant purchased from it 3,307 tons of companyl at the rate of Rs. 14-9-0 per ton between January 1952, and March 1953. The price for this companyl was Rs. 48,158-4-0.

facts.text: Respondent filed suit in Court of District Judge, Umaria claiming Rs. 52,514-14-0 including interest until date of suit.

anchor.surface_text: Since the appellant did number pay the price due from it the respondent filed the present suit in-the Court of the District Judge, Umaria, and claimed a decree for Rs. 52,514-14-0 including interest accrued due on the amount until the date of the suit.

facts.text: Date of suit is October 6, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: from October 6,1953, which was the date of the suit until the date of payment.

facts.text: Appellant disputed substantial part of claim, alleged amount arbitrarily calculated, paid for substantial part of coal, stopped purchasing from respondent and obtained supplies from Messrs Sood Brothers, Calcutta with payments made.

anchor.surface_text: A substantial part of, the respondents claim was disputed by the appellant. It was urged by the appellant in its written statement that the amount claimed by the respondent had been arbitrarily calculated and that for a substantial part of the companyl purchased by the appellant from the respondent due price had been paid.

facts.text: Appellant admitted liability of Rs.7,496-11-0 and expressed readiness to pay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant pleaded that for some time past it had stopped purchasing companyl from the respondent and it was obtaining its supplies from Messrs Sood Brothers, Calcutta, to whom payments for the companyl supply had been duly made. The appellant admitted its liability to pay Rs.7,496-11-0

facts.text: Trial court framed seven issues.

anchor.surface_text: On these pleadings the learned trial judge framed seven issues.

facts.text: On date for appellant's evidence, application for adjournment to produce additional evidence granted on condition of paying Rs. 200 costs to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on the date when the respondent led its evidence and the appellants turn to lead its evidence arrived an application for adjournment was made on its behalf to produce additional evidence which was granted on companydition that the appellant should pay to the respondent Rs. 200/- as companyts.

facts.text: Appellant did not appear nor pay costs on subsequent hearing date, trial court proceeded ex-parte.

anchor.surface_text: On the subsequent date of hearing, however, the appellant did number appear number did it pay companyts to the respondent as ordered. That is why the trial Court proceeded ex-parte against the appellant.

facts.text: Trial court passed ex-parte decree on November 9, 1954 for Rs. 52,535-7-0 with proportionate costs and interest at 6% per annum from October 6, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On the issues framed trial Court made findings in favour of the respondent in the light of the evidence adduced by the respondent and an ex-parte decree was passed against the appellant to the tune of Rs. 52,535-7-0 with proportionate companyts. The appellant was also ordered to pay interest at 6 per annum from October 6,1953,

facts.text: Appellant filed appeal in Court of Judicial Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh, Rewa on February 17, 1955, Appeal No. 16 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decree the appellant preferred an appeal in the Court of the Judicial Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh, Rewa, on February 17, 1955  Appeal No. 16 of 1955 .

facts.text: Last date for filing appeal was February 16, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Ramlal, one of the partners of the appellants firm, who was in charge of the limitation., fell ill on February 16, 1955, which was the last date for filling the appeal.

facts.text: Appellant filed application under s.5 Limitation Act on February 19, 1955 for condonation of one day's delay due to Ramlal's illness on February 16, 1955, supported by affidavit and medical certificate.

anchor.surface_text: On February. 19, 1955, the appellant filed an application under s. 5 of the Limitation Act and prayed that one days delay companymitted by it in filing the appeal should be companydoned because Ramlal, one of the partners of the appellants firm, who was in charge of the limitation., fell ill on February 16, 1955, which was the last date for filling the appeal. This application was supported by an affidavit and a medical certificate showing that Ramlal was ill on February 16, 1955.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner accepted that Ramlal was ill on February 16, 1955 but rejected condonation due to lack of diligence during the whole limitation period.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Commissioner, who heard this application, appears to have accepted the appellants case that Ramlal was ill on February 16 and that if only one days delay bad to be explained satisfactorily by the appellant his illness would companystitute sufficient explanation but it was urged. before him by the respondent that the appellant bad number shown that its partners were diligent during the major portion of the period of limitation allowed for appeal,

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Judicial Commissioner on August 6, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: and the appeal was dismissed on August 6, 1955.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner granted certificate under Art. 133 of Constitution due to conflict of judicial opinion on s.5 Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the Judicial Commissioner for a certificate and urged that on the question of companystruction of s. 5 of the Limitation Act there was a companyflict of judicial opinion and so the point decided by the Judicial Commissioner was one of general importance. This argument was accepted by the- Judicial Commissioner and so a certificate of fitness has been issued by him under Art. 133 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court condoned the one day delay and remanded the case to Judicial Commissioner for disposal on merits.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed, the delay of one day made in filing the appeal is companydoned, and the case sent back to the Court of the Judicial Commissioner for disposal on the merits in accordance with law.

facts.text: Appellant prepares and deals in limestone at Maihar and Satna, purchased coal for lime-kilns.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant prepares and deals in limestone at Maihar and Satna and for the use in their lime-kilns it purchased companyl from the respondents companyl-mines at Umaria by means of permits issued to it by Coal Commissioner Calcutta.

facts.text: Trial court made findings in favour of respondent based on its evidence.

anchor.surface_text: On the issues framed trial Court made findings in favour of the respondent in the light of the evidence adduced by the respondent

issues.text: The short question which falls to be considered in this appeal relates to the construction of s. 5 of the Indian Limitation Act IX of 1908.

anchor.surface_text: The short question which falls to be considered in this appeal relates to the construction of s. 5 of the Indian Limitation Act IX of 1908.

arguments.claim: S.5 discretion exercised to advance substantial justice with liberal construction of sufficient cause absent negligence during delay period

anchor.surface_text: s. 5 gives the Court a discretion which in respect of jurisdiction is to be exercised in the way in which judicial power and discretion ought to be exercised upon principles which are well understood the words sufficient cause receiving a liberal construction so as to advance substantial justice

arguments.claim: 'Within such period' means the period of delay from last day of limitation to filing date

anchor.surface_text: If the Judicial Commissioner had held that within such period means the period of the delay between the last day for filing the appeal and the date on which the appeal was actually filed he would undoubtedly have come to the conclusion that the illness of Ramlal on February 16 was a sufficient cause.

arguments.claim: Party entitled to wait until last day of limitation; no need to explain conduct during prescribed period

anchor.surface_text: It would not be reasonable to require a party to take the necessary action on the very first day after the cause of action accrues. In view of the period of limitation prescribed the party would be entitled to take its time and to file the appeal on any day during the said period

arguments.claim: Calcutta HC in Karalicharan Sarma correctly held sufficient cause only for last day needed, not whole period

anchor.surface_text: In Karalicharan Sarma v. Apurbakrishna Bajpeyi it appeared that the papers for appeal were handed over by the appellant to his advocate in the morning of the last day for filing the appeal. ... This decision is in favour of the appellant and is in accord with the view which we are inclined to take.

arguments.claim: Nagpur HC in Kedarnath v. Zumberlal wrongly requires explanation for waiting till last day

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, in Kedarnath v. Zumberlal the Judicial Commissioner at Nagpur has expressed the view that an appellant who willfully leaves the preparation ... until the last day ... is guilty of negligence ... This decision ... did not address ... construction of the section itself.

arguments.claim: Patna HC in Jahar Mal v. G. M. Pritchard wrongly denies condonation for waiting till last moment

anchor.surface_text: In Jahar Mal v. G. M. Pritchard the Patna High Court has adopted the same line. ... one is not entitled to put things off to the last moment ... These observations are subject to the same comment that we have made about the Nagpur decision.

arguments.claim: Even after sufficient cause, condonation not matter of right; discretion considers diligence but limited to post-sufficient cause facts

anchor.surface_text: even after sufficient cause has been shown a party is not entitled to the condonation of delay in question as a matter of right. The proof of a sufficient cause is a condition precedent ... diligence ... may fall for consideration but ... limited

arguments.claim: Diligence considerations more relevant under s.14 than s.5 alone

anchor.surface_text: considerations of bona fides or due diligence are always material and relevant when the Court is dealing with applications made under s. 14 of the Limitation Act. ... cannot to the same extent ... be invoked in dealing with applications ... only under s. 5

arguments.claim: Privy Council in Ram Narain Joshi not applicable as concerns different delay period

anchor.surface_text: In Ram Narain Joshi v. Parmeshwar Narain Mehta ... the question which arose was very different ... We do not see how this decision can assist us in interpreting the provisions of s. 5.

arguments.claim: Privy Council in Bri Indar Singh concerns s.14 with s.5, conditions not same for s.5 alone

anchor.surface_text: The next case ... Bri Indar Singh v. Kanthi Ram ... had reference to s. 14 read with s. 5 ... It would ... be unreasonable to suggest that the said conditions must to the same extent ... be taken into account in dealing with applications falling under s. 5

arguments.claim: Amount claimed arbitrarily calculated; substantial part paid; liability only Rs.7,496-11-0

anchor.surface_text: A substantial part of, the respondents claim was disputed by the appellant. It was urged by the appellant in its written statement that the amount claimed by the respondent had been arbitrarily calculated and that for a substantial part of the coal purchased by the appellant from the respondent due price had been paid. The appellant admitted its liability to pay Rs.7,496-11-0

arguments.claim: Ex-parte decree should be set aside and case remanded to allow appellant's evidence

anchor.surface_text: Against this decree the appellant preferred an appeal ... The main contention raised by the appellant in this appeal was that the ex-parte decree should be set aside and the case remanded to the trial Court with the direction that the appellant should be allowed to lead its evidence

arguments.court_reasoning: Remanded after condoning delay, merits not decided

arguments.claim: Appellant purchased 3,307 tons coal at Rs.14-9-0 per ton, total Rs.48,158-4-0 unpaid

anchor.surface_text: According to respondents case the appellant purchased from it 3,307 tons of coal at the rate of Rs. 14-9-0 per ton between January 1952, and March 1953. The price for this coal was Rs. 48,158-4-0.

holdings.text: The learned Judicial Commissioner was in error in holding that to show sufficient cause under s.5 Limitation Act, the appellant must explain its conduct during the whole period of limitation prescribed for the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: and the only point which has been urged on its behalf is that the Judicial Commissioner was in error in holding that in determining the question as to whether sufficient cause had been shown within the meaning of s. 5 of the Limitation Act it was necessary for the appellant to explain his conduct during the whole of the period prescribed for the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Erroneous construction of 'within such period'; text and context indicate it refers only to post-limitation delay period, not entire limitation period; unreasonable to require explanation for whole period as party entitled to wait till last day.

holdings.text: 'Within such period' in s.5 Limitation Act means the period of delay commencing from the last day of the prescribed limitation period, requiring sufficient cause only for that delay, not diligence during the entire limitation period.

anchor.surface_text: If the Judicial Commissioner had held that within such period means the period of the delay between the last day for filing the appeal and the date on which the appeal was actually filed he would undoubtedly have come to the conclusion that the illness of Ramlal on February 16 was a sufficient cause. That clearly appears to be the effect of his judgment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of phrase in context; party entitled to file on any day up to last day; repugnant to require explanation for prescribed period; resolves conflict of High Court views by approving Calcutta HC and distinguishing others.

holdings.text: Illness of Ramlal on the last day of limitation constitutes sufficient cause for the one-day delay in filing the appeal under s.5 Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: That clearly appears to be the effect of his judgment. That is why it is unnecessary for us to consider what is a sufficient cause in the present appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted by lower court if only one day; combined with correct construction of 'within such period', illness explains post-limitation delay satisfactorily.

holdings.text: Proof of sufficient cause is a condition precedent to the exercise of discretion under s.5 to condone delay; only after that does discretion arise, considering relevant facts like diligence but limited in scope.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, necessary to emphasise that even after sufficient cause has been shown a party is not entitled to the condonation of delay in question as a matter of right. The proof of a sufficient cause is a condition precedent for the exercise of the discretionary jurisdiction vested in the Court by s. 5.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory structure: sufficient cause mandatory before discretion; then liberal exercise to advance justice, distinguishing from s.14.

holdings.text: Considerations of bona fides and due diligence during the limitation period are material under s.14 Limitation Act but not to the same extent when dealing only with s.5.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection we may point out that considerations of bona fides or due diligence are always material and relevant when the Court is dealing with applications made under s. 14 of the Limitation Act. In dealing with such applications the Court is called upon to consider the effect of the combined provisions of ss. 5 and 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between standalone s.5 applications and those invoking s.14; s.14 expressly imposes such conditions.

holdings.text: The one-day delay in filing the appeal is condoned; appeal allowed and remanded to Judicial Commissioner for disposal on merits.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed, the delay of one day made in filing the appeal is condoned, and the case sent back to the Court of the Judicial Commissioner for disposal on the merits in accordance with law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.5: sufficient cause shown for delay; discretion exercised favourably absent other facts against appellant.

holdings.text: s.5 Limitation Act confers discretion to be exercised judicially with liberal construction of 'sufficient cause' to advance substantial justice where no negligence, inaction or lack of bona fides is shown.

anchor.surface_text: s. 5 gives the Court a discretion which in respect of jurisdiction is to be exercised in the way in which judicial power and discretion ought to be exercised upon principles which are well understood the words sufficient cause receiving a liberal construction so as to advance substantial justice when no negligence no inaction no want of bona fide is imputable to the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restatement of principle from precedents like Madras HC; guides exercise of discretion.

anchor.surface_text: As has been observed by the Madras High Court in Krishna v. Chattapan 1 s. 5 gives the Court a discretion which in respect of jurisdiction is to be exercised in the way in which judicial power and discretion ought to be exercised upon principles which are well understood the words sufficient cause receiving a liberal companystruction so as to advance substantial justice when numbernegligence number

precedents.cited_proposition: s. 5 gives the Court a discretion which in respect of jurisdiction is to be exercised in the way in which judicial power and discretion ought to be exercised upon principles which are well understood the words sufficient cause receiving a liberal construction so as to advance substantial justice when no negligence no inaction no want of bona fides is imputable to the appellant

anchor.surface_text: In Karalicharan Sarma v. Apurbakrishna Bajpeyi 2 it appeared that the papers for appeal were handed over by the appellant to his advocate in the morning of the last day for filing the appeal. Through pressure of urgent work the advocate did number look into the papers till the evening of that day when he found that was the last day. The appeal ,as filed the next day.

precedents.cited_proposition: it was enough if the appellant satisfied the Court that for sufficient cause he was prevented from filing the appeal on the last day and his action during the whole of the period need number be explained

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, in Kedarnath v. Zumberlal 3 the Judicial Commissioner at Nagpur has expressed the view that an appellant who wailfully leaves the preparation and presentation of his appeal to the last day of the period of limitation prescribed therefore is guilty of negligence and is number entitled to an extension of time if some unexpected or unforeseen companytingency prevents him from filing the appeal within time.

precedents.cited_proposition: an appellant who wilfully leaves the preparation and presentation of his appeal to the last day of the period of limitation prescribed therefore is guilty of negligence and is not entitled to an extension of time if some unexpected or unforeseen contingency prevents him from filing the appeal within time

precedents.citation: Jahar Mal v. G. M. Pritchard 4

anchor.surface_text: In Jahar Mal v. G. M. Pritchard 4 the Patna High Court has adopted the same line. Dawson Miller, C.J., brushed aside the claim of the appellant for companydonation of delay on the ground that ,one is number entitled to put things off to the last moment and hope that numberhing will occur which will prevent them from being in time.

precedents.case_name: Jahar Mal v. G. M. Pritchard
precedents.cited_proposition: one is not entitled to put things off to the last moment and hope that nothing will occur which will prevent them from being in time

precedents.citation: Ram Narain Joshi v. Parmeshwar Narain Mehta 5

anchor.surface_text: It number remains to refer to two Privy Council decisions to which our attention was drawn. In Ram Narain Joshi v. Parmeshwar Narain Mehta 5 , the Privy Council was dealing with a case where on August 9, 1895 the High Court bad made an order that the appeal in question should be transferred to the High. Court under s. 25 of the Code of Civil Procedure and heard along with another appeal already pending there.

precedents.case_name: Ram Narain Joshi v. Parmeshwar Narain Mehta
precedents.cited_proposition: delay between August 9, 1895 to September 16, 1895 had not been satisfactorily explained

precedents.citation: Bri Indar Singh v. K anshi Ram 6

anchor.surface_text: The next case on which reliance has been placed by the respondent is Bri Indar Singh v. K anshi Ram 6 . The Principal point decided in that had reference to 8. 14 read with 8. 5 of the Limitation Act, 1908 and the question which it was whether the time occupied by an application in food faith for review, although made upon a mistaken view of the law, should be deemed as added to the period allowed for presenting an appeal.

precedents.case_name: Brij Indar Singh v. Kanshi Ram
precedents.cited_proposition: whether the time occupied by an application in good faith for review, although made upon a mistaken view of the law, should be deemed as added to the period allowed for presenting an appeal under s.14 read with s.5

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; one-day delay in filing appeal condoned; case remanded to Judicial Commissioner for disposal on merits.
directions: case sent back to the Court of the Judicial Commissioner for disposal on the merits in accordance with law
appellant to pay the respondent the costs of this Court

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, necessary to emphasise that even after sufficient cause has been shown a party is not entitled to the condonation of delay in question as a matter of right. The proof of a sufficient cause is a condition precedent for the exercise of the discretionary jurisdiction vested in the Court by s. 5.

It is, however, necessary to emphasise that even after sufficient cause has been shown a party is not entitled to the condonation of delay in question as a matter of right. The proof of a sufficient cause is a condition precedent for the exercise of the discretionary jurisdiction vested in the Court by s. 5.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection we may point out that considerations of bona fides or due diligence are always material and relevant when the Court is dealing with applications made under s. 14 of the Limitation Act. In dealing with such applications the Court is called upon to consider the effect of the combined provisions of ss. 5 and 14.

In this connection we may point out that considerations of bona fides or due diligence are always material and relevant when the Court is dealing with applications made under s. 14 of the Limitation Act. In dealing with such applications the Court is called upon to consider the effect of the combined provisions of ss. 5 and 14.

In the result the appeal is allowed, the delay of one day made in filing the appeal is condoned, and the case sent back to the Court of the Judicial Commissioner for disposal on the merits in accordance with law.
Vohra, for the appellants. N. Pathak, R. Mahalingier and B. C. Mishra, for the respondent. 1961. May 4.
